#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk kexec-tools
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: kexec-tools bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The kexec-tools packages contain the /sbin/kexec binary and utilities that together form the user-space component of the kernel's kexec feature. The /sbin/kexec binary facilitates a new kernel to boot using the kernel's kexec feature either on a normal or a panic reboot. The kexec fastboot mechanism allows booting a Linux kernel from the context of an already running kernel. This update fixes the following bugs: When the "noauto" option was specified for NFS mounts in the /etc/fstab file, the kdump utility previously failed to create a vmcore dump file. With this update, kdump filters out "noatuo" if it is present in /etc/fstab, which allows core the dump file to be created correctly. (BZ#1186708) Prior to this update, if the iTCO_wdt watchdog device was activated while the system terminated unexpectedly, the vmcore dump file was not saved or saved only partially. With this update, the iTCO_wdt driver is able to stop the watchdog in case of a system crash, which allows kdump to properly create the dump file. (BZ#1066785) Due to incorrect DNS settings in the /etc/resolv.conf file, automatic network uploads of the vmcore dump file previously failed. This update modifies /etc/resolv.conf to allow DNS resolving to work properly. As a result, kdump now uploads the vmcore file successfully. (BZ#1196085) In addition, this update adds the following enhancements: The makedumpfile command now supports the new sadump format that can represent more than 16 TB of physical memory space. This allows users of makedumpfile to read dump files over 16 TB, generated by sadump on certain upcoming server models. (BZ#1195598) The name format of the directory generated for the vmcore dump file in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 has been modified to be consistent with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6. (BZ#1184562) Users of kexec-tools are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
